title: EDS 214: Analytical Workflows and Scientific Reproducibility
text:
Course Description
The generation and analysis of environmental data is often a complex, multi-step process that may involve the collaboration of many people. Increasingly, data scientists use tools that document and help to organize workflows to ensure reproducibility, shareability, and transparency of the results. This course will introduce students to the conceptual organization of workflows (including code, documents, and data) as a way to conduct reproducible analyses.
These concepts will be combined with the practice of various software tools and collaborative coding techniques to develop and manage multi-step analytical workflows as a team.




Conceptual model of an analytical workflow. Source: R for Data Science

title: EDS 214: Analytical Workflows and Scientific Reproducibility

Reproducible Workflows
EDS 214: Analytical Workflows and Scientific Reproducibility

Day 1 Morning | August 25th, 2025

title: EDS 214: Analytical Workflows and Scientific Reproducibility
text:
Welcome to EDS 214!

This is a class about workflows and reproducibility


The workflow is the fundamental unit of data science



Reproducibility ensures workflows don‚Äôt become dead ends



The concepts and skills in this class will keep coming up in future classes and for the rest of your career

title: EDS 214: Analytical Workflows and Scientific Reproducibility
text: Hi, I‚Äôm Max üëã

title: EDS 214: Analytical Workflows and Scientific Reproducibility
text:
What is a workflow?

THINK Take 1 minute to write down your own definition. Consider:

What are the components? How do they fit together?
Who is the audience?
What would the alternative be?

PAIR Turn to your neighbor and discuss your definitions
SHARE I will randomly call on a pair to share one shared element and one differing element

title: EDS 214: Analytical Workflows and Scientific Reproducibility
text:
What is a workflow?



Workflows combine: data, code, modeling, and communication.

Wickham, √áetinkaya-Rundel, and Grolemund (2023)

The final workflow masks a trajectory of exploration and dead ends

Stoudt, V√°squez, and Martinez (2021)

title: EDS 214: Analytical Workflows and Scientific Reproducibility
text:
What is reproducibility?


We define reproducibility to mean computational reproducibility ‚Äî obtaining consistent computational results using the same input data, computational steps, methods, code, and conditions of analysis

Reproducibility and Replicability in Science (2019)
DEBATE With your neighbor, discuss: does reproducibility matter if you‚Äôre not doing academic research?

What if you work for a public utility, a non-governmental organization, or a private firm?
Articulate one argument for and against the importance of reproducibility.
I will randomly call on a pair to share

title: EDS 214: Analytical Workflows and Scientific Reproducibility
text:
Global and local goals

Reproducibility is


GLOBAL GOAL

‚Ä¶ a means to verify results and ensure scientific integrity


LOCAL GOAL

‚Ä¶ a mechanism for knowledge transfer and collaboration



Feinberg et al. (2020)

title: EDS 214: Analytical Workflows and Scientific Reproducibility
text:
How does class work?

Reproduce a workflow (starting today!)
Lectures and interactive activities for learning goals

Automation
Organization
Documentation
Scale(ation)
Collaboration

title: EDS 214: Analytical Workflows and Scientific Reproducibility
text:
Specification-based grading


No points out of 100
A rubric of specifications (specs) for your final project
Meet (or exceed) specs and participate in class - get an A



Feedback loops are critical (no one-and-done)



You‚Äôll see more spec-based grading in other MEDS classes

title: EDS 214: Analytical Workflows and Scientific Reproducibility
text:
‚ÄúReproducible workflows saved my life <3‚Äù




Bekah Lane
Research Associate, Center for Coastal Studies

Question: Where are humpbacks in SF Bay most susceptible to ship strikes?
Problem: Complex data and model -> Iterating and incorporating feedback becomes time intensive -> Data, processing, and modeling become tangled - verifying results is hard!
Solution: Instead of a point-and-click solution in ArcGIS, a well-organized, reproducible workflow in R

title: EDS 214: Analytical Workflows and Scientific Reproducibility
text:
Works cited








Feinberg, Melanie, Will Sutherland, Sarah Beth Nelson, Mohammad Hossein Jarrahi, and Arcot Rajasekar. 2020. ‚ÄúThe New Reality of Reproducibility: The Role of Data Work in Scientific Research.‚Äù Proceedings of the ACM on Human-Computer Interaction 4 (CSCW1): 1‚Äì22. https://doi.org/10.1145/3392840.


Reproducibility and Replicability in Science. 2019. National Academies Press. https://doi.org/10.17226/25303.


Stoudt, Sara, V√°leri N. V√°squez, and Ciera C. Martinez. 2021. ‚ÄúPrinciples for Data Analysis Workflows.‚Äù Edited by Patricia M. Palagi. PLOS Computational Biology 17 (3): e1008770. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pcbi.1008770.


Wickham, Hadley, Mine √áetinkaya-Rundel, and Garrett Grolemund. 2023. R for Data Science: Import, Tidy, Transform, Visualize, and Model Data. 2nd ed. Sebastopol, CA: O‚ÄôReilly Media. https://r4ds.hadley.nz/.

title: EDS 214: Analytical Workflows and Scientific Reproducibility
text:
This is a class about workflows and reproducibility
The workflow is the fundamental unit of data science
Reproducibility ensures workflows don‚Äôt become dead ends
The concepts and skills in this class will keep coming up in future classes and for the rest of your career

title: EDS 214: Analytical Workflows and Scientific Reproducibility
text:
Hi, I‚Äôm Max

I started as a computer scientist
Software engineer at Microsoft
Four years as a field biologist (seabirds, mostly)
Six years grad school, specializing in data science

GIS at SFSU
Marine biology at Stanford

My specialty was biologging - animal-borne sensors for detecting location, behavior, and physiology
Now my research is about open science, sharing data and code, and the ethics of proprietary data
But really what I love is teaching!
In addition to the MEDS program, I also teach in the new marine science undergraduate major
My favorite part of my job is working with students

I would love it if you set up a meeting with me to tell me about your background, your interests, and your motivations for being here

title: EDS 214: Analytical Workflows and Scientific Reproducibility
text:
What is this class about?

What is a workflow?

Think-pair-share activity
Data, code, modeling, communication
The final workflow masks a trajectory of exploration and dead ends (Stoudt et al.¬†2021 doi:10.1371/journal.pcbi.1008770)

What is reproducibility?

Does it matter if you‚Äôre not doing academic research?
Debate activity
Reproducibility is the ability to repeat a workflow and get the same results
Global and local goals

‚Äúreproducibility as a mechanism for local knowledge transfer and collaboration, particularly as regards efficient software reuse‚Äù (Feinberg et al.¬†2020 doi:10.1145/3392840)

title: EDS 214: Analytical Workflows and Scientific Reproducibility
text:
How does it work?

Beginning today, try to reproduce a workflow
Lectures and hands-on activities for:

Automation
Organization
Documentation
Scale(ation)
Collaboration

Specification-based grading

No points out of 100
A rubric of specifications (specs) for your final project
Meet (or exceed) specs and participate in class - get an A
Feedback loops are critical (no one-and-done)
You‚Äôll see more spec-based grading in other MEDS classes

title: EDS 214: Analytical Workflows and Scientific Reproducibility
text:
Testimonial from Bekah??

Question: where are humpbacks in SF Bay most susceptible to ship strikes?
Problem: model eats a lot of data with extensive pre-processing and subjective parameters.

Time consuming to iterate and incorporate feedback.
Easily becomes tangled - verifying results is hard!

Solution: instead of a point-and-click solution in ArcGIS, a well-organized, reproducible workflow in R.
Today: Bekah is Research Associate with the Center for Coastal Studies in Provincetown, MA. Still doing field work and data analysis to protect whales in coastal waters with high human impacts.

title: Workflows and reproducibility
text:
Further reading

Stoudt, V√°squez, and Martinez (2021) describe how analytical workflows evolve, what they look like in the end, and how they‚Äôre necessary for data-intensive science.
Lowndes et al. (2017) present a case study on their own team-based research. They show how an emphasis on reproducibility improves efficiency as well as transparency.

title: Lab 1.1 KEY
text:
# load packages ----
library(tidyverse)
library(palmerpenguins)

title: Lab 1.1 KEY
text:
# load packages ----
library(tidyverse)
library(palmerpenguins)

title: Lab 1.1 KEY
text:
Tidy Data Review
Example untidy / wide data:

# create some untidy temperature data ----
temp_data_wide <- tribble(
  ~date, ~station1, ~station2,  ~station3,
  "2023-10-01", 30.1, 29.8,  31.2,
  "2023-11-01", 28.6, 29.1,  33.4,
  "2023-12-01", 29.9, 28.5,  32.3
)

# print it out ----
print(temp_data_wide)

# A tibble: 3 √ó 4
  date       station1 station2 station3
  <chr>         <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl>
1 2023-10-01     30.1     29.8     31.2
2 2023-11-01     28.6     29.1     33.4
3 2023-12-01     29.9     28.5     32.3


Using pivot_longer() to ‚Äúlengthen‚Äù / tidy our data:

# convert data from wide > long ----
temp_data_long <- temp_data_wide |> 
  pivot_longer(cols = starts_with("station"),
               names_to = "station_id",
               values_to = "temp_c")

# print it out ----
print(temp_data_long)

# A tibble: 9 √ó 3
  date       station_id temp_c
  <chr>      <chr>       <dbl>
1 2023-10-01 station1     30.1
2 2023-10-01 station2     29.8
3 2023-10-01 station3     31.2
4 2023-11-01 station1     28.6
5 2023-11-01 station2     29.1
6 2023-11-01 station3     33.4
7 2023-12-01 station1     29.9
8 2023-12-01 station2     28.5
9 2023-12-01 station3     32.3

  geom_point()
